section: Section 1: Fundamentals of Hardware and Software
objective: Identify and explain the function of hardware components.
content: Structure and function of the Central Processing Unit (CPU), various input/output devices, and storage media (primary vs secondary).
specific_objectives: Describe the internal hardware components: CU, ALU, and registers
Differentiate between primary storage (RAM, ROM) and secondary storage (HDD, SSD, cloud)
Categorize input/output devices (manual vs automated, specialized)
Explain the role of biometrics and sensors in automated data entry
Discuss the factors influencing computer performance (CPU speed, RAM capacity)

section: Section 1: Fundamentals of Hardware and Software
objective: Distinguish between types of software and their functions.
content: Classification of software into system software (OS, Utilities) and application software. Understanding user interfaces and licensing.
specific_objectives: Define System Software and Application Software
Identify the functions of an Operating System (memory management, task scheduling)
Differentiate between Command Line Interface (CLI) and Graphical User Interface (GUI)
Distinguish between proprietary software, open-source, and shareware/freeware
Describe the role of utility programs: defragmenters, antivirus, compression tools

objective: Analyze the process of converting data into information.
content: The data processing cycle, data types, and methods of data capture. Focuses on the importance of accuracy and integrity.
specific_objectives: Distinguish between data and information
Describe the stages of the data processing cycle (Input, Processing, Output, Storage)
Identify various data types (text, numeric, date, boolean)
Explain data validation techniques (range check, type check, length check)
Explain data verification techniques (double entry, visual check)
Discuss the sources of data (primary vs secondary) and methods of collection

section: Section 3: Computer Networks and Web Technologies
objective: Explain the concepts and terminology related to networking.
content: Network types (LAN, WAN, MAN), topologies, and communication media. Transition from traditional to cloud-based networking.
specific_objectives: Define a computer network and state its benefits
Differentiate between LAN, WAN, and MAN
Describe client-server vs peer-to-peer architectures
Identify wired (twisted pair, fiber optic) and wireless (Wi-Fi, Bluetooth) media
Explain the function of network hardware: routers, switches, network interface cards (NICs)
Discuss the concept of Cloud Computing and its service models (SaaS, PaaS, IaaS)

section: Section 3: Computer Networks and Web Technologies
objective: Understand the components and evolution of the World Wide Web.
content: The Internet vs the WWW, URLs, protocols (HTTP, FTP), and web accessibility.
specific_objectives: Define the Internet, Intranet, and Extranet
Deconstruct a Uniform Resource Locator (URL)
Describe the role of web browsers and search engines
Identify common web protocols: HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SMTP
Discuss the importance of web standards and accessibility

section: Section 4: Implications of Misuse and Cybersecurity
objective: Analyze the social and ethical issues related to computing.
content: Malware, illegal acts (hacking, identity theft), and the digital divide. Ethical use of technology in society.
specific_objectives: Define various types of malware: viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware
Explain social engineering attacks: phishing, vishing, baiting
Discuss the legal implications of computer misuse (Computer Misuse Act)
Analyze the impact of the 'Digital Divide' on Caribbean society
Identify green computing practices and their environmental importance

section: Section 4: Implications of Misuse and Cybersecurity
objective: Evaluate methods for protecting data and systems.
content: Authentication techniques, encryption, firewalls, and disaster recovery planning.
specific_objectives: Compare authentication methods: passwords, biometrics, two-factor authentication (2FA)
Describe the role of firewalls and encryption in data protection
Explain the importance of regular data backups and UPS systems
Analyze the components of an effective physical security strategy
Identify best practices for personal cybersecurity (safe browsing, software updates)

section: Section 5: Data Analysis and Web Page Design
objective: Utilize spreadsheets for numerical analysis and modeling.
content: Formulae, relative vs absolute referencing, pivot tables, and advanced charting.
specific_objectives: Use basic and advanced functions (SUM, AVERAGE, IF, VLOOKUP, COUNTIF)
Explain the difference between relative and absolute cell referencing
Apply formatting techniques to enhance data presentation
Create and interpret various chart types for data visualization
Perform 'What-if' analysis using spreadsheet models

section: Section 5: Data Analysis and Web Page Design
objective: Design and manage structured data using a database management system.
content: Tables, queries, forms, and reports. Primary/Foreign keys and relationships.
specific_objectives: Define key database terms: file, table, record, field
Explain the purpose of a Primary Key and a Foreign Key
Create one-to-many and many-to-many relationships
Perform complex queries using multiple criteria (AND, OR, NOT)
Design user-friendly forms and professional reports

section: Section 5: Data Analysis and Web Page Design
objective: Develop simple web pages using standard tools and languages.
content: Sitemaps, HTML tags, CSS for styling, and web hosting basics.
specific_objectives: Draft a sitemap to plan website structure
Use basic HTML tags (head, body, p, h1, img, a) to structure a page
Apply CSS for consistent styling (color, font, layout)
Evaluate a website's usability and navigation
Describe the process of publishing a website to a web server

objective: Apply a systematic approach to solving computational problems.
content: Defining the problem (IPO diagrams), algorithms, and top-down design.
specific_objectives: Deconstruct a problem into Input, Processing, and Output (IPO)
Represent problem solutions using Flowcharts (standard symbols)
Represent problem solutions using Pseudocode
Explain the concept of 'stepwise refinement' or 'top-down design'
Identify logic errors and trace algorithms using trace tables

objective: Analyze and optimize the structure of algorithms.
content: Selection and iteration structures. Nesting and efficiency considerations.
specific_objectives: Implement selection structures (IF-THEN-ELSE, CASE)
Implement iteration structures (FOR, WHILE, REPEAT-UNTIL)
Demonstrate the use of nested control structures
Discuss the criteria for an 'elegant' or efficient algorithm

objective: Translate algorithms into high-level programming language code.
content: Syntax, variable declaration, data types, and compilers vs interpreters.
specific_objectives: Distinguish between low-level (machine, assembly) and high-level languages
Declare and initialize variables and constants
Identify basic data types (Integer, Real, String, Char, Boolean)
Explain the difference between a Compiler and an Interpreter
Describe the stages of the program development life cycle

objective: Write, test, and debug code using structured programming.
content: Input/Output statements, arithmetic operators, and testing strategies.
specific_objectives: Write code to perform input and output operations
Use arithmetic, relational, and logical operators in expressions
Perform internal documentation (comments) for code readability
Differentiate between syntax errors, run-time errors, and logic errors
Apply testing techniques (dry run, test data sets) to verify code correctness
